/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Hello, I would like to send attention to Wu. Thanks in advance, Hirotaka.

Hi Wu! Could you please check this? Here are some points to review.

* The Nova API added "userdata" parameter and deprecated the "files" parameter[1]. "config_drive" parameter is irrelevant. 
* However, recent patch[2] in Trove changed the "config_drive" parameter value by changing the default value of "use_nova_server_config_drive" in trove.conf. I think we should revert that part. 
* prepare_cloud_config function is a really good job, but this PR changes the prepare_cloud_config function a little because I think this function should prepare userdata only when files is defined, which is based on Nova API specification change. 
* Recent patch[2] in Trove changed the existing test code(test_servers_create_block_device_mapping_v2), but I think it should be avoided unnecessaily. This PR reverts that part.

---
[1]: https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/126c3d4c78d937888213979272534e1cb706a4d4
[2]: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/trove/+/823632

Hi Wu, sorry for my late reply. I think there are two ways to add ssh-key to Trove Guest OS. I will investigate the second way this week.

1) Add ssh-key to guest os statically
ssh-key is injected by the following dib scripts.
https://github.com/openstack/trove/blob/master/integration/scripts/files/elements/ubuntu-guest/extra-data.d/11-ssh-key-dev

2) Add ssh-key to guest os dynamically by using Nova Create Server API
ssh-key is injected by Nova Create Server API. The API document says:
> Include the key_name parameter in the create request body to add a keypair to the server when you create it.

I will investigate how the Nova API parses the parameters and passes the parameter values to cloud-init this week.
https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=create-server-detail#create-server
I'm owner of patch [2]. I had some comment. please review.

Hi,Hirotaka  thanks a lot , yes, We need add Openstack as datasource for cloud init. As Tran mentioned, config-driver doesn't support live migration, And the previous patch has converted the files to user-data. Trove agent should also work with config-driver=false now. What will we benefit from if we revert the config-driver to true ?
ok, I will take some time to review this ps.

Hi Wu, Thanks for your comments! 

> As Tran mentioned, config-driver doesn't support live migration, 
Yes! I understand that Trove users who use nova's live migration feature must use "config_drive=False" when calling the Nova API. When calling the nova API with "config_drive=False", I think all Trove users have to configure config-init to read files from meta data service instead of config drive even if they don't use nova's live migration feature.

> And the previous patch has d the files to user-data. 
Yes, user-data is a recommended alternative to files. 

One point to remember is that "use_nova_server_config_drive=False" is not necessary to read user-data because cloud-init can read user-data from meta data service by using "curl http://169.254.169.254/openstack/latest/user_data". However the current code seems that "use_nova_server_config_drive=False" is required to convert files to user-data. I think this should be fixed.

> Trove agent should also work with config-driver=false now. 
Yes, it also works for me, but in my case, I added the following setting to /etc/cloud/cloud.cfg in my image to read user-data from meta data service.
```
datasource_list: [  ConfigDrive, OpenStack, None ]
```

> What will we benefit from if we revert the config-driver to true ?
There is a benefit for users who currently configure cloud-init to read user-data from config-drive. If we revert that, they need not to change their guest images when updating OpenStack version to Yoga. If we don't revert that, the required files(controller.conf, guest_info.conf and trove-guestagent.conf) for guest-agent are not created in their guest instances and guest-agent fails to start after their updates.

I'm a little worried that changing config-driver setting possibly causes a negative influence and some users have to change their configuration to avoid that. In addition, we don't know how many users need to change their configuration. As I reported in my previous comment, the cloud-init setting environment(DIB_CLOUD_INIT_DATASOURCES) in Trove is "ConfigDrive". 

I think that patch[1] is confusing a bit, because changing the default value is not required to adapt to file injection deprecation. I understand live migration is very useful in some cases, but as Nova's document[2] says some hypervisor drivers are not support live migration. This means to me that we should discuss more on using live migration in Trove as a default.

---
[1]: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/trove/+/823632
[2]: https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/admin/configuring-migrations.html

Hi Wu, I have investigated the nova API and the Trove guest image. Arguments passed by the openstack server create API appear in both config drive and the metadata service.

To enable the config drive for an instance, we pass "config-drive=true" to the openstack server create API. However, cloud-init behavior actually depends on cloud-init configuration in guest images. The current cloud-init configuration in Trove's guest image is:

---/etc/cloud/cloud.cfg.d/91-dib-cloud-init-datasources.cfg---
"datasource_list: [  ConfigDrive, None ]"
---/etc/cloud/cloud.cfg.d/91-dib-cloud-init-datasources.cfg---

This means cloud-init still gets metadata from config drive even if we pass "config-drive=false" to the openstack server create API. If we really want to disable config-drive, we have to use metadata service to get metadata. So we have to change cloud-init configuration in guest images like this:

---/etc/cloud/cloud.cfg.d/91-dib-cloud-init-datasources.cfg---
"datasource_list: [  ConfigDrive, OpenStack, None ]"
---/etc/cloud/cloud.cfg.d/91-dib-cloud-init-datasources.cfg---

For a Trove user, we currently have no reason to change the "config-drive" value because nova's config_drive is not relevant with files deprecation. I think we should put the config_drive parameter value back to True. Changing the existing guest images for no sufficient reasons is not welcome to normal users.

Hi Wu, I have investigated the reason why the "use_nova_server_config_drive" directive was introduced[1]. The commit log says:
```
Fix broken instance provisioning with disabled volume support

Reasons:
 - in certain deployments that has disabled volume support, different volume types
   (iSCSI instead of virtio) Trove doesn't inject trove-guestagent.conf, userdata,
   disables "config-drive"-based injection
Changes:
 - refactoring code to use one common function to prepare files and usedata
 - adding to Nova call:
   - config_drive parameter;
   - userdata
```

I think changing the default value of the directive to "False" means Trove doesn't inject trove-guestagent.conf. So Trove users have to choose either A or B to avoid the problem.

A. Change "use_nova_server_config_drive" in trove.conf to True explicitly and then restart Trove.
B. Change their guest images to make cloud-init inject user-data by using metadata service.

I don't understand the reason to have changed the default value to "False" well. As I commented previously changing the default value  is not necessary to adapt nova's file deprecation.

Thanks in advance,
Hirotaka
 
---

Hi Bo, Thank you very much for explaining your code change to me! Let me explain my code change. Firstly we must prevent trove from using –personality to inject files while booting an instance via Nova api. As nova api says[1], let's use the configuration drive, because it is the standard way for users to inject user data into their server instance.
```
if personality_files_found; then
    convert_the_personality_files_to_user_data
fi
```
As as result, my code is like this:
```
if files:
    userdata = self.prepare_cloud_config(files)
```

My understanding is that your patch achieves two things, but is it correct? Firstly trove stops using –personality to inject files while booting an instance via Nova api. Secondarily, trove starts using 'config_drive=False' as default while booting an instance via Nova api.

The first goal is what we must achieve and I totally agree with it, but I think the secondary one is currently not for everyone's goal. I understand live migration is very important and ceph is sometimes a necessary for that, but we need more discussion about live migration before changing the current way to create an instance. Let's think about deprecating file injection and live migration separately.

I would like to make a suggestion. Let's add CONF.use_nova_live_migration_ceph and code like:
```
if CONF.use_nova_server_config_drive:
    server = self.nova_client.servers.create(config_drive=False, ...)
```
If we approach the goal this way, current users can update the OpenStack version without changing their trove.conf.

---
[1]: https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/queens/implemented/deprecate-file-injection.html

SC2086: Double quote to prevent globbing and word splitting
https://github.com/koalaman/shellcheck/wiki/SC2086
If use "file_debian", the "*" in it will not expand. Wrong results are got.

It looks to me like you should expand the glob only at the time of setting the ${file_debian} variable.  That way you don't have to worry about quotes preventing the globbing.  And your script won't barf with syntax errors if the glob expansion just happens to include more than one file.

Here's a quick example:

bash-4.2$ cat test
#!/bin/bash

BOB="1*lst"

if [ ! -f ${BOB} ]
then
  echo "test 1: bob is not a regular file"
fi
# These quotes prevent glob expansion
if [ ! -f "${BOB}" ]
then
  echo "test 2: bob is not a regular file"
fi

# Instead, set BOB to the expanded list in advance
BOB=(1*lst)

echo "${BOB}"

if [ ! -f "${BOB}" ]
then
  echo "test 3: bob is not a regular file"
fi
bash-4.2$ ./test
test 2: bob is not a regular file
1860193.lst
bash-4.2$

pam-config/debian/deb_folder/pam-config..message: Why are these not directly installed to /etc/pam.d ?

For two reasons:
1. Originally these files are installed directly in /etc/pam.d, but the package built that way can't be uninstalled and purge. Actually there is Debian document says never use dpkg-divert for conffiles.
2. Using a staging directory to copy these files is following what the other config files are handled. I think this make sense, because we can use the same mechanism to do package upgrade for all these config file packages (needed for patching and system upgrade).

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: recheck

Going back in history it looks like setting the 'owner' actually never worked. Not in the initial commit [1], not in Ansible 2.9 [2] and not today, although it has been documented from the beginning.

OpenStack Image API defines parameter 'owner' as:

"An identifier for the owner of the image, usually the project (also called the “tenant”) ID. The value might be null (JSON null data type)." [3].

With DevStack's current Horizon Dashboard I cannot see how one could change this value. OpenStack Client has an '--project' parameter which allows to change the 'owner_id' (in master [4]) or 'owner' (in stable/train [5]) to a project. I would prefer to use the same approach as the OpenStack Client: Drop the owner parameter in our cloud.openstack.image module and add a 'project' parameter instead.

Keeping the 'owner' parameter would be a deviation from our usual approach because it accepts no name, only an id.

What do you think?

[1] https://github.com/ansible/ansible/commit/a4e4dbd863b531774b782fdc38fc75e2549ef3f7
[2] https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blame/stable-2.9/lib/ansible/modules/cloud/openstack/os_image.py
[3] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/image/v2/index.html?expanded=show-image-detail
[4] https://opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient/src/commit/dabaec5a7b1b9786a8f91eebef738bf755faf059/openstackclient/image/v2/image.py#L398
[5] https://opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient/src/commit/de0be9db05ac2fe955b014b05f2e03411e684494/openstackclient/image/v2/image.py#L316

Should the input to the `owner` field be validated here? I believe the value is supposed to be a project ID, but it seems that glance allows arbitrary strings. `python-openstackclient` tries to find the project ID for a given owner name or ID. What is `ansible-collections-openstack`'s position on this?

It seems that OpenStack Client made a deliberate choice to use `--project` instead of `--owner` ([1]). Unfortunately there is no indication on why this was done.
If the usual behaviour is to accept names and IDs then adding a `project` parameter and resolving both is probably the best way forward. This would imply to add a `project-domain` parameter as well in order to resolve project names in other domains.



[1]
https://opendev.org/openstack/python-openstackclient/commit/cf2de9af79cedd51ca080f5a6521997c05647418
Thanks for the clarification! Maybe you want to add this to the commit message so that later editors know why you changed from owner to project?

- Verify that subcloud reconfigure post upgrade is successful

neutron/agent/common/ovs_lib.py.message:
Not sure if this is a rollback of batch flow installtion, since one port can produce a large sets of flows as well. The flows are generated based on the ports number of the group, number of security group rules and remote security group. The OF flow installation timeout is the main pain point here. Too many flows may cause the ovs-agent failed to restart forever. Too long timeout of the OF action may cause the ovs-agent failed to process new resource. The operators need to estimate the scale of their cloud, and set a timeout value. And remember to adjust it at the right time according to the scale.

Something out of the scope here, the scale can be:
1. Maximum resource capacity of one host
2. Maximum resource capacity of one network
3. Maximum resource capacity of one security group
4. How long they can bear that the resource action is "Unable to respond"
5. How many hosts the cloud have

I'm aware this is a kind of revert of [1]. However this patch is not submitting all processed rules at once but only one port related flows.

Of course, as you commented, depending on the number of rules per port, the number of flows could be considerable. However, adding 1000 or 2000 flows could take 1 or 2 seconds.

Furthermore, according to the bugs related to [1], I don't see any reference to any problem when adding large sets of flows:
- https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1813703: with several related bugs. Some of them related to timeouts when dumping flows or RPC timeouts, but nothing related to flow insertion.
- https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1813704: same RPC timeout problem, already addressed.
- https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1813707: almost a duplicate bug.

So I see no reason not to include this patch. If we have timeouts inserting one port flows, we'll have for sure when dumping all table flows. I would also like to remark that the port flow insertion uses ovs-vsctl, not as dump-flows or other flow insertions (that use native implementation).

[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/638642
Nit: new param should be added to the tail to avoid some unexpected call failed.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Excuse my wall of text, but I would like for this discussion to end fruitfully - be it a reviewed and accepted spec or a rejected feature.



I read the discussion from your last meeting  (https://meetings.opendev.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2021-11-23.log.html)
and am wondering if there is a way going forward with this proposal, meaning making changes to the spec and then consequently to the already
existing implementation and code jhartkopf wrote (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/816157) to allow for mutable userdata.
If I may sum up what I believe is the current state of things:


1) Use-cases for cloud administrators to modify instance userdata

 First of all, I would fully agree to ditch all potential cloud administrator use-cases for mutating the userdata from this spec.
 This data should solely remain in the domain of the user.



2) Use-cases which benefit from mutable user-data

One major part of the discussion was the lack of use-cases. We established that the  use-cases for mutable user-data certainly are more with
clients other than cloud-init. As even though it does allow to be run on every boot, this scenario less common.
But other tools, clients and approaches on consuming user-data can benefit from it being mutable by the user during the life of an instance (not requiring a rebuild):


 a) First there is cloudbase-init (https://github.com/cloudbase/cloudbase-init/), which is quite common for Windows machines running on OpenStack.
    This is the use-case we hit after a customer raised a support case about being unable to update the userdata of an instance.
    Cloudbase-Init documents their plugins being run on every boot, picking up changes in userdata.
    While it's certainly possible to e.g. modify the timeservers manually or via config management after the instance has been brought up,
    allowing for mutable user-data keeps all those settings and changes in a single place.
    Provided there is no proper config management being used anyways and only settings taken from the initial user-data are changed.
    See point #3 for more on the documentation of mutable user-data.


 b) Cloud-Native / Ephemeral Operating systems

    There are OS which are not managed in a traditional sense, with packages being installed via package management
    and a config management tool being used to configure them. But rather an ephemeral image to which a single config "file" is applied.

    Some examples are:

      * TalosOS https://www.talos.dev/docs/v0.13/cloud-platforms/openstack/#compute-creation
      * Rancher
      ** K3OS: https://github.com/rancher/k3os#phases // https://github.com/rancher/k3os#etc
      ** Rancher RKE: https://rancher.com/docs/rancher/v2.5/en/cluster-provisioning/rke-clusters/options/#cluster-config-file

    even though the instances of such OS could also be rebuild, a reboot with a changed configuration is usually much quicker.
    And not all clouds have OpenStack Heat available to manage the migration of an instance pool from one config to the other.


 c) Scripts to setup instance after boot

    I understand that looking towards other (public) clouds does not make for a use case for mutable userdata in itself.
    But taken from the prominently documented ability to update userdata and to place scripts there to run certain basic steps
    on every boot - this is an actively applied design practice in cloud environments:
      * https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/ec2-windows-user-data.html#user-data-execution
      * https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/user-data#what-is-user-data
      * ...

    being able to edit this script is all that mutable user-data would provide.

    This approach is not about managing packages or modifying config files, which is the job of a config management -
    no objections to what your said Sean.
    But rather to allow for less modifications of the instance and rather use a script to apply startup parameters or e.g.
    join commands for some clustered software. And those instructions might change.

    This is somewhat similar to (b), having an image containing all the packages and userdata just being the "configuration" source.
    Similar to a container receiving environment variables or a config file, but being immutable otherwise.


 d) NFV or other virtual appliances which consume their "config" via userdata.

    Apparently Vadim Ponomarev had some particular examples.



2) Compatibility with config drive

  Sean you said "jhartkopf: we could proably make it mutable if there is a use facing usecase but we would need to support config dirve and note that the change may not fully be ableable untill after a hard reboot".

  As for the config drive there are multiple ways dealing with mutable userdata
  if a config drive is used:

  a) Allow it and document clearly that the content of the drive will only be visible to the instance after a reboot.
  b) Reject it always and respond to the API call with a clear message indicating that userdata cannot be updated if a config drive is used.
  c) Reject it for running instances with an equally clear message instructing the user to shut the instance down prior to the change of userdata.

  Reading your statement again, Sean, I believe you like (a) the most?



3) Documentation

  As for every feature the documentation should also guide the user in making the best use of it. In this case the documentation shall point out clearly that:

  "User data is a blob of data that the user can specify when they launch an instance and modify it afterwards.
  The instance can access this data through the metadata service or config drive.
  Nova does not provide any form of syntax validation, state or config management. This data and even more any mutation to it during the instance lifetime,
  needs to make sense to a particular client-side software on the instance."

  (As addition to https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/user/metadata.html#user-data)

I miss two things to be defined in the spec:

* When and how nova will regenerate the config drive, and how the new config drive will be plugged to the instance, if we allow update while the instance is running.

* How can guest consume the updated data if cloud-init only reads that at firstboot. I see that discussion about it is ongoing. That is good, let's document the result of that.

Sorry but I feel strongly against this proposal : the use cases don't sound to me legit. For sure, you *COULD* modify the user data if you like, but you *CAN* also use config management tools for achieving such things.
The mission of Nova has never been to provide external tools for managing the application level but rather providing APIs that can help such tools for managing the created instances.

Thank you Sean for picking up on this new spec so quickly and for your kind review and rich comments.
I added some responses and comments to your remarks.

How can we proceed with the discussion to get a nice and focused spec ready?
This idea has been discussed multiples times and quite thoroughly in the blueprint https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/userdata-modification and there even was (at least) one implementation done (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova-specs/+/547964/), unfortunately then abandoned.

There even was an approved spec https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/newton/approved/user-data-modification.html

Jan did pick up on this and implemented the required changes to the nova API and the novaclient:

* https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/816157
* https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-novaclient/+/816158


And in the review Takashi Natsume pointed out, that writing a spec for this feature as first step would make sense.

Vadmin, Pavel, Mikhail, Tetiana - I took the liberty to add you as reviewers to this proposed spec since you did support a similar spec for the OpenStack Rocky release (https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova-specs/+/547964/) and were talking about use cases in which user_data holds config data for e.g. a Juniper vSRX (NFV) or similar virtual appliances and having the capability to update the user_data was beneficial to having to go through a rebuild.
Maybe your use-cases are still valid and you could kindly contribute to this review as well?


Steve you did write the blueprint (https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/update-userdata) also proposing the capability to update the user_data of an instance.

im not fully conviced that this is the right way to approch this.

i think this is yet another usecasue that would be better served by an extention to the resize api to allow resizing to the same flavor and in this case also allow updated to the user data as part of that operation.

or better a dedeicated recreate instnace action but if we were to proceed with this as planned we would either need to require the vm is stop when the update is done or document that the change will not fully take effect until the instnace has been hard rebooted or moved via a cold migration or shleve/unshelve.

Certainly the implications of a required reboot depending on consuming piece of software would need to be well documented. But they are the same as on other platforms which support updates to the user_data. 

Requiring the instance to be stopped (as AWS does) has the downside, that declarative tools like Terraform have a hard time to make use of the new flexibility.

The intention for this spec/change was mainly to support updating user_data in the metadata service.
While there are definitely people using a config drive, I would suggest to not support this use case and stick with the metadata service.
Config drives are static by design and do not fit the possibility to dynamically update user_data.

When someone updates user_data via the new microversion's extended PUT API, we could check whether the instance uses a config drive and reject the update request in that case.

Would this approach be sufficient to handle the usage of config drives?


To address your second point, as Christian already mentioned, there are many different ways for a guest to consume the updated user_data. For example, they could reset the current cloud-init state and re-init, or use custom software which parses the current user_data in the metadata service.
(Of course, this could be a manual process to start in addition to calling the Nova API.)

Hey Christian! We resolved our issues by creating the patch for our fork of OpenStack Nova. 3 years ago we pushed these changes to Rocky to implement such functionality in upstream but for now we do not want to spend a time for this.

Updating user_data via a rebuild is already possible (https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=rebuild-server-rebuild-action-detail#rebuild-server-rebuild-action).
I don't think this would be a fitting solution as it adds basically the same feature just to another API (and even requires calling the existing Rebuild API afterwards).

The whole point of this spec is to be able to update user_data without rebooting or rebuilding the instance. If someone wants to change user_data and is fine with rebuilding, they can simply use the rebuild action.

We tried to implement this feature 5 months in the linked patchset, despite the fact that adding improvements to the upstream didn't help us in any way. The patchset just waited for review for 2 months from core reviewers. In the end, it became clear to us that no one except us needed it. So I don’t understand why we should waste our extra time on this.
Nowadays we are still using this patch in production and changing it for newer releases every year. With this patch, we are setting SSH keys inside VM because the usual way doesn't work with multiple keys, and doesn't work with domain-level users.
The use case for NFV is still valid but we are not using NFVs in our infrastructure now.

I've updated the spec to reflect the latest results of our discussion.
some more nits inline but i think this is at least workable.

As I already said, I have concerns with the fact that userdata is mutable. If so, this would mean that when changing a value, we wouldn't longer know whether the related instance continues to use the orginal value or the new one. 

Also, I'm not convinced we *really* need to change this given there are already configuration tools that support the needed use cases. This doesn't really look as a nova scope : https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/contributor/project-scope.html#no-more-orchestration

I actually don't hate this idea. When I read the title, I immediately thought of (IMHO) the similarity between server metadata and server userdata. Given that we allow multiple ways to mutate metadata, I'm not sure that allowing replacement of userdata is such a stretch.

I don't think you should change the spec based on my inline comments at this stage, given the reservations from other reviewers. I just wanted to add my high level thoughts about it.
Is there any way to go forward with this?

Sylvain,

I tried as best as I can to reply to your comments inline.
But I believe some of the discussion was lost here between review and resulting revisions.

Maybe, if you even tentatively could agree with the ideas behind this proposal, I gladly discuss more.
While I understand you concerns about adding functionality that may confuse users or facilitates use cases which have may side effects.

But quite honestly it just extends on the existing ability to modify metadata items (usually consumed the same way user-data is). And metadata items very much are mutable (https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=create-or-update-metadata-items-detail#create-or-update-metadata-items). They are just a little less flexible / commonly used.

Thus the ideas to add a bit of (totally optional) flexibility to use the user-data.

While I absolutely agree with the rule of not doing any orchestration, having user-data mutable during the lifecycle of an instance is merely "orchestration".
It's just dead data living in an API reach to be fetched an consumed. And the consumption of it is the actual orchestration. And certainly that's the job of cloud-init or all the other tools like cloudbase-init, ignition or a simple script interpreter running on the machine - so making use of that data.

Having it mutable just allows from some use-cases to benefit from user-data without actively adding any control loops or "orchestration".

If cloud-init was the only consumer of such data I'd fully agree.

But actually the user_data available via the metadata service is one thing and cloud-init making use of that data is another. As stated, other platforms / cloud providers do allow updates, and also even promote the capability to run a (changeable) script on every boot: https://aws.amazon.com/premiumsupport/knowledge-center/execute-user-data-ec2/

We always designed user_data to be immutable as it caches a lot of image information besides the networking details. As you also mentioned, cloud-init exposes a cache to know whether it's a first boot or not, so we want it to be idempotent ideally.

As for Ignition the project itself fully agrees with you: https://coreos.github.io/ignition/rationale/#ignition-runs-only-on-the-first-boot
But there projects making use of Ignition which also clearly document the way to rerun it, e.g. Flatcar Linux: https://www.flatcar-linux.org/docs/latest/provisioning/ignition/boot-process/#reprovisioning

Cloud-Init clearly makes are distinction between first-boot and consequent boots https://cloudinit.readthedocs.io/en/latest/topics/boot.html#first-boot-determination documenting what can be done when.

as a result if we were to niavly recreate the config drive it woudl cause the instance to loose data as all injected files would be lost.

so we would have to reopen the orginial config drive and then update its content.

File injection should not be of interest in this case when we only support updating data in the metadata service.

Either way, file injection is deprecated and should not be required to be supported by this change.

you can do this with some other configuration management tools than cloud-init, right?

Yes. If I may point you to section 2) of my lengthy "wall of text" in my previous reply to this patchset. There I listed some use-cases, if I may quote:

>2) Use-cases which benefit from mutable user-data
>
>One major part of the discussion was the lack of use-cases. We established that the  use-cases for mutable user-data certainly are more with
>clients other than cloud-init. As even though it does allow to be run on every boot, this scenario less common.
>But other tools, clients and approaches on consuming user-data can benefit from it being mutable by the user during the life of an instance (not requiring a rebuild):
>
>    a) First there is cloudbase-init (https://github.com/cloudbase/cloudbase-init/), which is quite common for Windows machines running on OpenStack.
>        This is the use-case we hit after a customer raised a support case about being unable to update the userdata of an instance.
>        Cloudbase-Init documents their plugins being run on every boot, picking up changes in userdata.
>        While it's certainly possible to e.g. modify the timeservers manually or via config management after the instance has been brought up,
>        allowing for mutable user-data keeps all those settings and changes in a single place.
>        Provided there is no proper config management being used anyways and only settings taken from the initial user-data are changed.
>        See point #3 for more on the documentation of mutable user-data.
>
>    b) Cloud-Native / Ephemeral Operating systems
>        There are OS which are not managed in a traditional sense, with packages being installed via package management
>        and a config management tool being used to configure them. But rather an ephemeral image to which a single config "file" is applied.
>        Some examples are:
>
>        * TalosOS https://www.talos.dev/docs/v0.13/cloud-platforms/openstack/#compute-creation
>        * Rancher
>        ** K3OS: https://github.com/rancher/k3os#phases // https://github.com/rancher/k3os#etc
>        ** Rancher RKE: https://rancher.com/docs/rancher/v2.5/en/cluster-provisioning/rke-clusters/options/#cluster-config-file
>
>        even though the instances of such OS could also be rebuild, a reboot with a changed configuration is usually much quicker.
>        And not all clouds have OpenStack Heat available to manage the migration of an instance pool from one config to the other.
>
>    c) Scripts to setup instance after boot
>        I understand that looking towards other (public) clouds does not make for a use case for mutable userdata in itself.
>        But taken from the prominently documented ability to update userdata and to place scripts there to run certain basic steps
>        on every boot - this is an actively applied design practice in cloud environments:
>        * https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/ec2-windows-user-data.html#user-data-execution
>        * https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/user-data#what-is-user-data
>        * ...
>
>        being able to edit this script is all that mutable user-data would provide.
>        This approach is not about managing packages or modifying config files, which is the job of a config management -
>        no objections to what your said Sean.
>        But rather to allow for less modifications of the instance and rather use a script to apply startup parameters or e.g.
>        join commands for some clustered software. And those instructions might change.
>
>            This is somewhat similar to (b), having an image containing all the packages and userdata just being the "configuration" source.
>        Similar to a container receiving environment variables or a config file, but being immutable otherwise.
>
>    d) NFV or other virtual appliances which consume their "config" via userdata.
>        Apparently Vadim Ponomarev had some particular examples.
>

Sean did respond with some suggestions to phrase a particular use-case (like the time servers example) which was then simply used for the following revision of the spec. Certainly more verbosity on use-cases could be applied to the spec - as you can read I have a hard time keeping myself from creating long paragraphs :-)

That would mean that we need to reboot the instance to get the updates, right ?

If so, how an user could know whether the userdata values are related to the existing instance or not ?

Yes and no. The data is simply provided by the API / metadata service and any change would be  available immediately after mutation. But, as you said, there rightfully is no orchestration in Nova. That's the job of whatever the user uses for his workflow to change the user data in the first place. IaC tools like terraform or pulumi or even a script using the openstack-client could trigger the reboot after a change.

Looking at the existing api-ref, I tend to think this should rather follow the format of the server metadata replacement [1] API, for example:

 PUT /servers/{server_id}/userdata

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/?expanded=#replace-metadata-items
OK, but this would mean that the already created instance wouldn't use the values that are updated, until someone asks to reboot the instance, right?

Yes - depending on the consuming client software only running on reboot. As I said the mutated data would be available immediately.

If you accept my brave comparison - it's a little like the Kubernetes ConfigMaps. They are just resources holding arbitrary data. Updating a config map will, in case it's mounted as a volume and not exposed as environment variables, update immediately to the Pod (https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/configuration/configmap/#mounted-configmaps-are-updated-automatically). 

But actually reacting to the change is the job of the workload there as the ConfigMaps (or Secrets for that matter) are literally just some (mutable) piece of data being provided.
see, here you need to reboot.

Maybe it's just me but I would have thought option a) would be the most consistent and intuitive way to handle config drive. That is, the user can update nova's storage of the server's userdata via 'PUT /servers/{server_id}/userdata' whether it's using config drive or not, and if it uses config drive, the user has to hard reboot it to effect the update in the guest.

I say the above having had past experience using nova guests as my dev boxes in and injecting ssh keys and so on through userdata + cloud-init + config drive. And if I had had the ability to change the userdata with a PUT API, I would have expected the guest would need a reboot of some kind to consume the new userdata. It feels intuitive, at least to me.

If I may refer my lengthy post again - this was just one option to deal with a config drive.

>2) Compatibility with config drive
>
>    Sean you said "jhartkopf: we could proably make it mutable if there is a use facing usecase but we would need to support config dirve and note that the change may not fully be ableable untill after a hard reboot".
>    As for the config drive there are multiple ways dealing with mutable userdata
>    if a config drive is used:
>        a) Allow it and document clearly that the content of the drive will only be visible to the instance after a reboot.
>        b) Reject it always and respond to the API call with a clear message indicating that userdata cannot be updated if a config drive is used.
>        c) Reject it for running instances with an equally clear message instructing the user to shut the instance down prior to the change of userdata.
>
>        Reading your statement again, Sean, I believe you like (a) the most?


Sean like rejecting the change and guiding the user trough a hard reboot the most here to that was written as "the solution" to the spec.


I could totally agree to any of the solutions. The Config drive is, excuse my comparison to Kubernetes gain, like having a ConfigMap as environment variables which require a Pod deletion to be applied.

The linked documentation provides the full context but I'll sum it up here.

Python metadata specifications as defined in PEPs 314, 349, 459 and 566, which are compiled in Core metadata document[3], allow for multiple build systems to implement the required functionality. The required functionality being limited in the extreme. 

We, and entire Openstack afaik, are using Setuptools with a pbr[4] extension.

Unfortunately, when we the repo was initiated, syntax from other build system, namely flit, got in, while one other field was in the wrong section.
So far we have been lucky, possibly thanks to pbr, or due to the general leniency of the Python ecosystem. But there is no guarantee that in the future the standards won't be enforced more diligently. We should get ahead of this while we can. 

As for the classifiers. Those are entirely optional and only used for cataloguing packages in repos. We could get rid of all of them, or make them up, and it would make little difference in practical terms. However they do help to make sense of what the package actually is for outside observer. 

[3]https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/specifications/core-metadata/
[4]https://docs.openstack.org/pbr/latest/

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_cephadm/de.message:
We don't want to have problems if these variables are unset so this patch is good for fixing that. However, the fix should only be in deployed_ceph.yaml.j2 so that it correctly handles if they are not defined.

I don't think we should set default values here since we don't want to pass CephPools: [], CephClientUserName: '', and CephClientKey: '' to THT under any circumstance. We prefer the defaults that THT has instead (including how it generates a cephx password for the key). We only include them in deployed_ceph.yaml.j2 if the operator chose to set them via the tripleo python client so that we can be consistent.
